Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Process Development across Alloy Systems for Powder Bed Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project will apply fundamental research to the problem of controlling melt pool dimensions and microstructure for electron beam direct metal powder bed additive manufacturing processes. Specifically, it will address how to transfer control methods developed for one material system to another material system in a way that reduces costly and time-consuming experimentation. To accomplish this, this project will develop a first-of-its kind modeling-based process mapping approach for application across different materials used in direct metal powder bed additive manufacturing processes. Process mapping methods will be applied to experiments performed on multiple metal alloys using additive manufacturing equipment available to the investigators.

Direct metal additive manufacturing is of great interest to the aerospace, medical implant, and other industries. It offers the promise of decreased manufacturing cost, substantial reductions in the amount of material used to build a component, and the ability to fabricate structures not realizable by conventional manufacturing methods. Two barriers to widespread use of direct metal additive manufacturing in the aerospace and other industries are (1) the lack of a platform for transferring process knowledge (for example, how to build shapes) from one metal alloy system to another; and (2) limited knowledge about controlling microstructure and mechanical properties for any alloy system. These barriers lead to expensive, costly experimentation in applying additive manufacturing to new material systems and the inability to certify mechanical strength in fabricated components. This project will overcome both of these barriers through research accomplished by a team that includes academic investigators from three universities (North Carolina State, Carnegie Mellon and Wright State) and a collaborator from the aerospace industry currently working to integrate direct metal additive manufacturing into component production (Pratt & Whitney).

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Additive manufacturing (AM) offers distinct advantages over traditional manufacturing processes in terms of reduced lead time, reduced material usage, and ease of replicating complicated geometries. However, qualification of AM processes to build advanced components such as those in the aerospace industry has proven to be very expensive and time consuming.  As a result, the adoption of these techniques is being inhibited. The greatest current challenge is the experimentation and time required to develop process parameters for new material systems and developing the relationships between process inputs and process outputs such as microstructure which govern the material properties. The objective of this research is to make process development and qualification economical and extendable to multiple alloy systems through minimum experimentation and modeling work.

 

Toward this goal, the process mapping technique was applied on powder bed electron beam melting (EBM) of Nickel super alloys Inconel718 (IN718), Inconel625 (IN625) and Ti-6Al-4V (Ti64) to study the effect of primary process variables on process outputs of melt pool geometry and microstructure. Primary process variables considered in this work are beam power, travel velocity, background temperature, deposition geometry and material feed rate. Findings from finite element models and experiments suggest that there are process variable combinations that yield consistent melt pool geometry and solidification cooling rates. This result has then been used to non-dimensionalize the process variables and thermophysical properties of the materials.  This has yielded an alloy-independent framework to estimate melt pool geometry and solidification conditions for process development with minimal trial and error work.

 The greatest impact of this project are:

(i)             Developing the experiment and simulation set up to characterize the material behavior in the available process space in a systematic manner. These results are used to develop melt pool geometry and microstructure process maps.

(ii)            Developing a non-dimensional alloy-independent framework to estimate the melt pool geometry and solidification conditions across alloy systems in EBM for materials with different thermophysical properties and for various process variable combinations. This will aid in reducing the number of experiments and simulations that needs to be performed to test every process variable combination.

(iii)          Demonstrating location-specific microstructure control for the aerospace alloy Ti-6Al-4V (Ti64) in EBM which can be achieved by any user with basic EBM machine training. This will allow for engineering of the material properties of electron beam melted components.

 

Overall, this work brings us a step closer towards accelerated process development and qualification procedures in additive manufacturing.

 


Last Modified: 04/17/2017
Modified by: Jack L Beuth
